facts.text: On August 3, 1953, Government of West Bengal referred industrial dispute under s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act to second Industrial Tribunal between appellant company and its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: the facts leading to the appeal are that on August 3, 1953, the Government of West Bengal referred under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, hereinafter called the Act,

facts.text: During pendency of reference, workmen surrounded E.L. D'Cruz, acting Works Manager, confined him from 9:15 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. until rescued by police.

facts.text: Cause of workmen's action was dispute over payment of Puja bonus for 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The cause of this action on the part of the workmen is stated to be a dispute as to the payment of Puja bonus for the year 1953.

facts.text: On same day, workmen went on strike at 9:15 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant- companypany issued numberices at 9-45 a. m., and 10-45 a.m. asking the workmen to resume work immediately.

facts.text: Appellant company served charge sheets on workmen requiring explanations within 24 hours; workmen gave explanations; enquiry held; workmen found guilty of gross misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: were then arrested. The appellant companypany then served charge sheet on the workmen calling upon them to submit their explanations within 24 hours.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not argued before tribunals; parties proceeded on basis of 67/64

holdings.text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal erred by sitting in appeal against the managerial enquiry and re-appreciating evidence on identity of workmen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied principles from Indian Iron & Steel Co.: tribunal interferes only for want of good faith, victimization, natural justice violation, or perverse finding; LAT reweighed credibility impermissibly.

holdings.text: Proceedings before Industrial Tribunal and Labour Appellate Tribunal arose under s.10 reference, not s.33/33A; misconception vitiated LAT order.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal seems to have overlooked the fact that the appeal before it arose out of a Reference made by the West Bengal Government under s. 10 of the Act. This misconception as to the nature of the proceedings vitiated its order as the Appellate Tribunal misdirected itself as to the scope of the powers to be exercised by it

holdings.reasoning_summary: LAT treated as s.33 permission or s.33A contravention, but was full adjudication under s.10 on dismissal justification.

holdings.text: No infraction of natural justice in managerial enquiry; service of charge sheets by registered post to registered addresses, affixing on notice boards inside/outside, and letter to union complied with standing orders.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing orders permit oral, notice board, or communication; management made every reasonable effort despite non-cooperation.

holdings.text: Managerial enquiry not vitiated; complied with principles of natural justice per standing orders on major misdemeanours (illegal strike, insubordination).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Strike illegal under s.22; service mode followed; opportunity given.

holdings.text: S.33 proceedings are for prima facie permission only, not adjudication; no res judicata effect barring subsequent s.10 enquiry or dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in this contention, which seems to be based on a misapprehension as to the nature and scope of proceedings under s. 33. That section does not confer any jurisdiction on a Tribunal to adjudicate on a dispute but it merely empowers the Tribunal to give or withhold permission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object is to prevent victimization during pendency; permission lifts ban without final merits decision; cites precedents like Atherton West, Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills.

holdings.text: No basic error in management's findings justifying tribunal interference.

anchor.surface_text: No basic error is therefore made out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alleged discrepancy in numbers not argued below; parties proceeded on 67/64 basis; falls within Indian Iron principles.

holdings.text: Dismissals of workmen justified; appeal allowed, LAT decision and IT award (for Nos. 2-24) set aside; no reinstatement or compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal as to all the workmen and the award of the Industrial Tribunal as to workmen Nos. 2 to 24 are set aside and the claim for compensation which was argued before us is disallowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: proper enquiry, no jurisdictional error by management, illegal strike, compliance with procedures; lower tribunals erred.

precedents.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

precedents.citation: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  2

anchor.surface_text: The principles which govern the power of an Industrial Tribunal to interfere with the decision of the employer following an enquiry made by him were laid down by this Court in Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  2  where K. Das J., said at page138

precedents.case_name: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: principles governing power of Industrial Tribunal to interfere with employer's enquiry findings: interfere only if want of good faith, victimisation, unfair labour practice, basic error or violation of natural justice, or perverse finding
precedents.cited_holding: Undoubtedly, the management of a companycern has power to direct its own internal administration and discipline but the power, is number unlimited and when a dispute arises, Industrial Tribunals have been given the power to see whether the termination of service of a workman is justified and to give appropriate relief. In cases of dismissal or misconduct, the Tribunal does number, however, act as a Court of appeal and -substitute its own judgment for that of the management. It will interfere  i -when there is want of good faith,  ii  when there is victimisation or unfair labour practice,  iii  when the management has been guilty of a basic error or violation of a principle of natural justice, and  iv  when on the materials, the finding is companypletely baseless or perverse.

precedents.citation: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup

anchor.surface_text: In Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup which was a case under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, this Court held that if it was established that the workmen had resorted to illegal strike, that a fair enquiry into the alleged misconduct and insubordination of their workmen had been held by the management without violating any principles of natural justice and as a result of enquiry the management had found the workmen guilty of misconduct and insubordination with which they had been charged and the management had companye to the companyclusion that companytinuing the workmen in its employ was dangerous in the interest of the companypany the Tribunal would number interfere with such order.

precedents.case_name: Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Pt. Ram Sarup
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal would not interfere with management's order of dismissal if illegal strike, fair enquiry without violation of natural justice, and management found guilty and continuation dangerous to company

precedents.citation: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das  2

anchor.surface_text: In Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das  2  it was held that numberappeal lies against the order of an Industrial Tribunal where the Tribunal had examined the question whether the discretion of the employer to dismiss certain workmen was properly exercised, whether the employer was acting bona fide, whether he had resorted to any unfair labour practice or victimization and whether his desire to dismiss the workmen was actuated by any improper motive.

precedents.case_name: Hanuman Jute Mills v. Amin Das
precedents.cited_proposition: no appeal lies against Industrial Tribunal order if it examined employer's discretion, bona fides, no unfair practice or victimization, no improper motive

precedents.citation: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union  1

anchor.surface_text: Atherton West Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mill Mazdoor Union  1 , Lakshmi Devi Sugar Mills v. Pt. Ram Sarup  2 . In the Automobile Products of India Ltd. v. Rukmaji Bala  3 4V44  Das J.,  as be then was  said at p. 1256-- The purpose of these two sections  s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act and s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act  being to determine whether the ban should be removed or number, all that is required of the authority exercising jurisdiction under these two sections is to accord or withhold permission .

precedents.citation: Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: It was next companytended that in the present case there was a basic error within the meaning of the rule laid down by S. Das J., in Indian Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen 1 . anchor.surface_text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal seems to have overlooked the fact that the appeal before it arose out of a Reference made by the West Bengal Government under s. 10 of the Act. This misconception as to the nature of the proceedings vitiated its order as the Appellate Tribunal misdirected itself as to the scope of the powers to be exercised by it

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in this contention, which seems to be based on a misapprehension as to the nature and scope of proceedings under s. 33. That section does not confer any jurisdiction on a Tribunal to adjudicate on a dispute but it merely empowers the Tribunal to give or withhold permission
